description: From Middle English chaufour, chafour, from Anglo-Norman chaufour, from Latin calefactōrium; equivalent to chafe +‎ -er.

entries.meaning: A vessel for heating water; hence, a dish or pan.
examples: A chafer of water to cool the ends of the irons.

entries.meaning: A vessel for holding burning coals or hot water used  as a warmer.

description: From Middle English chafur, chavere, from Old English ċeafor, from Proto-West Germanic *kefrō (“beetle”). Cognate with German Käfer and Dutch kever.

entries.meaning: Any of several scarab beetles, including the cockchafer, leaf chafer, and rose chafer.
examples: He who torments the Chafers spriteWeaves a Bower in endleſs Night
